comments:
When in the debugger, since around 3.1M2/3 the several of our eclipse platforms
have been failing with the message Exception processing async thread queue. 
This usually happens when we click on a member variable that has a large or
complicated data structure underneath.  Sometimes we can get around this by
clicking on the plus sign instead of the variable name.

The below exception was pulled from the log after trying to use a euclidean
distance computation in a conditional break point.  First 3-4 times it did the
same things.  It did finally work a few times later.  So, this doesn't happen
always, but frequently.  It rarely happened before 3.1.  

!MESSAGE Exception processing async thread queue
!SUBENTRY 1 org.eclipse.jdt.debug 4 120 2005-04-11 09:47:32.785
!MESSAGE Exception processing async thread queue
!STACK 0
java.lang.ClassCastException:
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.core.model.JDIObjectValue
	at
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.eval.ast.instructions.ArrayAccess.execute(ArrayAccess.java:35)
	at
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.eval.ast.engine.Interpreter.execute(Interpreter.java:50)
	at
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.eval.ast.engine.ASTEvaluationEngine$1$EvaluationRunnable.run(ASTEvaluationEngine.java:355)
	at
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.core.model.JDIThread.runEvaluation(JDIThread.java:558)
	at
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.eval.ast.engine.ASTEvaluationEngine$EvalRunnable.run(ASTEvaluationEngine.java:389)
	at
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.core.model.JDIThread$ThreadJob.run(JDIThread.java:2417)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:67)

If you have an example you can attach that causes the problem, it would help 
us track the problem down.
Marking as REMIND until further input is provided.
